awd_titl_txt: Building Recruiting and Inclusion for Diversity (BRAID) in the Computer Science Major: A Longitudinal Research Study
awd_abstract_narration:
In an effort to improve an understanding of how computer science (CS) departments can successfully diversify their undergraduate enrollments, this project will support the longitudinal follow-up of students taking introductory CS courses at fifteen (15) universities across the country.  All fifteen CS departments have a stated commitment to diversify their major and are participants in the Building, Recruiting and Inclusion for Diversity (BRAID) initiative.  BRAID institutions have committed to a set of approaches to increase diversity within CS departments, including modifying introductory courses to make them more attractive and less intimidating to underrepresented students.  

This research will focus on the ways in which introductory courses promote interest and persistence in CS, with a special focus on what is most successful for women and underrepresented minority students.  Students will be surveyed while taking the introductory course about their experiences in the courses as well as their self-perceptions, perceptions of CS, major choice selection, and career plans. This research will extend a baseline data collection project currently being done into a longitudinal study.  Students from the baseline study will be followed beyond the introductory courses and surveyed annually through the spring semester of the 2018-2019 academic year.  Doing so will allow the research team to assess student experiences beyond the introductory course, such as involvement in CS extracurricular activities, as well as measure a variety of outcomes, such as student enrollment patterns (e.g., choosing CS as a major or minor) and career plans, across time. Findings from this study will provide policy-makers, higher education administrators, faculty, and the general public with new knowledge about the most effective ways to recruit and retain more individuals into the computing field.  Further, this study will provide additional knowledge about how to diversify computing by increasing the number of women and underrepresented minorities who complete CS majors and minors.

por.por_cntn:
Momentum: Accelerating Equity in Computing and Technology is a research group led by Drs. Linda J. Sax and Kathleen J. Lehman in the School of Education & Information Studies at UCLA. From 2015 to 2021, the Momentum team conducted a longitudinal study of two cohorts of students who took an introductory computer science (CS) course in 2015-2016 or 2016-2017 at 15 universities across the U.S. The institutions involved in this study were part of the Building Recruiting and Inclusion for Diversity (BRAID) project and made a commitment to diversifying the undergraduate CS major. BRAID institutions sought to increase women's and Black, Latinx, and Indigenous (BLI) students' participation in CS by implementing initiatives across four main areas of focus, including modifying introductory courses to make them more attractive to women and BLI students, increasing outreach efforts to high school teachers and students, building confidence and community among women and BLI students, and developing and/or promoting double majors in areas like CS and Biology that may be more attractive to students from marginalized groups.

The overarching goal of this project was to examine the impact of students' exposure to and participation in departmental best practices on students' decisions to pursue and persist in computing over several years. Specifically, the research team surveyed introductory computer science course students at the beginning of their course and at the end of their course. Approximately 10,000 unique individuals took one or both of those baseline surveys. Then, we surveyed these students annually for four or five years after completing the course. The project followed both CS majors and non-majors who took an introductory CS course and measured how certain environmental factors, such as the inclusion of real-life problems in introductory courses, participation in computing organizations, or exposure to specific pedagogies, related to outcomes such as completing a CS minor/major or planning to pursue a career in computing. In doing so, the study contributes to literature and practice in several important ways. First, we provide insights to scholars, administrators, and policymakers about how students who take introductory CS courses perceive the departmental climate and their own abilities, and how these perceptions vary among students of different gender and racial/ethnic identities. Second, following-up with these students longitudinally enabled us to learn how these students' perceptions changed over-time, as well as to study the longer-term role of a variety of environments and outcomes. Additionally, we have learned a great deal about students who take an introductory CS class but do not major in CS; this population is increasingly important to understand, as there is growing awareness of the interdisciplinary nature of CS. Thus, this longitudinal study revealed new information on the impact of introductory CS courses for both majors and non-majors. 

 


Last Modified: 12/14/2021
Modified by: Linda J Sax
